bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, July 5, 1898

div1.p: Reed informs Sternberg that Edward Mason Parker is a most competent physician. [Courtesy of the National Library of Medicine]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, July 5, 1898
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
July 5th '98
My Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Permit
me to introduce to you
my very good friend,
Dr Edward Mason Parker.
The doctor needs no
Endorsement from me
as to his professional
qualifications. After
spending one year under
Welch at laboratory work
(he was in my class) he
entered the Johns Hopkins
Hospital where he did
good work for more
than 2 years. During
this time he was, also,
Holstead's Assistant.
I know him to be a
most competent Physician
Surgeon and one who
could be depended
upon, under all Cir-
cumstances. Should Dr
Arthur (who, by the way!
I see from N. Y. Times, is
to have a relief ship) need
a first class man, he
could not get a better
one than Dr Parker.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, yours, Walter Reed, Surg. Gen. Sternberg
U.S.A.
